facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 764 of 1954 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 764 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated May 9, 1963 of Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 2272 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated May 9, 1963, of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 2272 of 1959.

facts.text: Respondents Ram Chand and Kailash Chand are tenants of premises municipal No. 863 at Jumna Kinara Road, Agra, commonly known as Putaria Mahal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are the present tenants of the premises bearing municipal No. 863, situated at Jumna Kinara Road, Agra, companymonly known as Putaria Mahal.

facts.text: Predecessors-in-interest of respondents let into possession by appellants Lala Shri Bhagwan and Shrimati Gopal Devi.

anchor.surface_text: Their predecessors were let into possession as tenants by the appellants, Lala Shri Bhagwan and Shrimati Gopal Devi, on an agreement that they would pay a monthly rent of- Rs. 58-4-0

facts.text: Tenancy agreement for monthly rent of Rs. 58-4-0 from Sudi 1 to Badi 15 of each Hindi month.

anchor.surface_text: on an agreement that they would pay a monthly rent of- Rs. 58-4-0 and that the tenancy would companymence from the Sudi 1 of each Hindi month and end on Badi 15 of the next month.

facts.text: Appellants applied to Rent Controller and Eviction Officer under s.3 for permission to file ejectment suit against predecessors of respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The two appellants applied to the Rent Controller and Eviction Officer  hereafter called the Officer , under s. 3 of the Act for permission to file a suit in ejectment against the predecessors-in-interest of the respondents.

facts.text: Officer granted permission on September 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Officer granted permission by his order passed on September 1, 1951.

facts.text: Respondents appealed to Additional District Magistrate who remanded case for fresh hearing.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then moved the Additional District Magistrate, who had been authorised by the District Magistrate to hear appeals against the decision of the Officer. The appellate authority declined to companyfirm the permis- sion granted to the appellants and remanded the case to the Officer for a fresh hearing.

facts.text: Officer rejected appellants' application on August 9, 1952 after re-hearing.

anchor.surface_text: On re-hearing the matter, the Officer changed his view and rejected the appellants application for permission on August 9, 1952.

facts.text: Appellate authority granted permission to appellants on December 9, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On December 9, 1952, the appellate authority ordered that permission should be granted to the appellants for suing the respondents in ejectment.

facts.text: Commissioner of Agra allowed respondents' revision and set aside appellate order on February 4, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On February 4, 1953, the revisional authority allowed the revisional application and set aside the appellate order granting permission to the appellants.

facts.text: State Government under s.7-F directed Commissioner to revise order on May 7, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On May, 7, 1953, the State Government directed the Commissioner to revise his order on the ground that it thought that the need of the appellants was genuine.

facts.text: Commissioner cancelled previous order and confirmed permission on July 28, 1953 pursuant to State Government direction.

anchor.surface_text: Acting in pursuance of this direction, the Commissioner passed an order on July 28, 1953, by which he cancelled his previous order and companyfirmed the order passed by the appellate authority, granting permission to the appellants to sue the respondents in ejectment.

facts.text: State Government did not hear respondents Ram Chand and Kailash Chand before passing s.7-F order.

anchor.surface_text: whether the revisional order passed by the State Government of Uttar Pradesh under s. 7-F of the Uttar Pradesh  Temporary  Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947  hereinafter called the Act , is rendered invalid by reason of the fact that before passing the said order, the State Government did number hear the two respondents, Ram Chand and Kailash Chand, who were affected by it.

facts.text: Appellants filed ejectment suit in Civil Judge, Agra after permission.

anchor.surface_text: After this order was passed, the appellants sued the respondents in ejectment in the companyrt of the Civil Judge, Agra.

facts.text: Trial court passed decree in favour of appellants on August 31, 1957, finding permission valid.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the trial companyrt passed a decree in favour of the appellants on August 31, 1957.

facts.text: Respondents' appeal dismissed by First Additional Civil Judge, Agra on May 30, 1959, confirming findings including permission validity.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal companyrt companyfirmed all the findings recorded by the. trial Judge, with the result that the respondents appeal was dismissed, on the 30th May, 1959.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court allowed respondents' second appeal on May 9, 1963, holding State Government permission invalid for lack of hearing.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the second appeal preferred by the respondents was allowed and the appellants suit ordered to be dismissed.

facts.text: Respondents resisted ejectment suit on several grounds including validity of permission.

anchor.surface_text: The claim made by the appellants for ejectment of the respondents was resisted by them on several grounds, and on the companytentions raised by the respondents, the trial companyrt framed six issues.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court Division Benches previously held s.7-F orders administrative, no need for hearing.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that this question had been companysidered by Division Benches of the Allahabad High Court in the past and the companysensus of judicial opinion appears to have been in favour of the, view that the revisional order which the State Government is authorised to pass under s. 7-F, is number a quasi-judicial order but is a purely administrative order

facts.text: Uttar Pradesh Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947 enacted due to accommodation shortage.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed in 1947 and its main object obviously was, in the words of the preamble, to companytinue during a limited period powers to companytrol the letting and the rent of residential and number-residential accommodation and to prevent the eviction of tenants therefrom.

issues.text: whether the revisional order passed by the State Government of Uttar Pradesh under s. 7-F of the Uttar Pradesh Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947, hereinafter called the Act, is rendered invalid by reason of the fact that before passing the said order, the State Government did not hear the two respondents, Ram Chand and Kailash Chand, who were affected by it

anchor.surface_text: The short question of law which arises in this appeal by special leave is whether the revisional order passed by the State Government of Uttar Pradesh under s. 7-F of the Uttar Pradesh  Temporary  Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947  hereinafter called the Act , is rendered invalid by reason of the fact that before passing the said order,

issues.text: what is the nature of the proceedings taken before the State Government under s. 7-F and what is the character of the jurisdiction and power conferred on the State Government by it; are the proceedings purely administrative, and can the State Government decide the question and exercise its jurisdiction without complying with the principles of natural justice?
whether the District Magistrate in exercising authority under s. 3 of the Act is required to act quasi-judicially and follow principles of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: under s. 3 of the Act for permission to file a suit in ejectment against the predecessors-in-interest of the respondents. ... the revisional order which the State Government is authorised to pass under s. 7-F, is number a quasi-judicial order but is a purely administrative order,

issues.text: whether the Commissioner in exercising revisional power under s. 3(3) of the Act is required to act quasi-judicially and follow principles of natural justice

anchor.surface_text: In 1952, clauses  2 ,  3  and  4  were added to s. 3 by the Amending Act 24 of 1952. ... The Commissioner shall hear the application made under sub-section  2 , as far as may be, within six weeks from the date of making it,

arguments.claim: Revisional order under s.7-F is not a quasi-judicial order but purely administrative, no need to hear parties

anchor.surface_text: It appears that this question had been considered by Division Benches of the Allahabad High Court in the past and the consensus of judicial opinion appears to have been in favour of the, view that the revisional order which the State Government is authorised to pass under s. 7-F, is not a quasi-judicial order but is a purely administrative order,

arguments.court_reasoning: Scheme of s.3 shows DM and Commissioner act quasi-judicially with natural justice requirements; s.7-F partakes same character for ends of justice

arguments.claim: State Government under s.7-F required to act quasi-judicially and follow principles of natural justice including opportunity to be heard

anchor.surface_text: the State Government in exercising its authority under s.7-F of the Act, had not given an opportunity to the respondents to be heard. He took the view that in exercising its authority under s. 7-F, the State Government was required to decide the matter in revision in a quasi-judicial manner and it was absolutely essential that the principles of natural justice

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed based on statutory scheme, tenant rights affected, and need for judicial approach

arguments.claim: Previous Division Bench decisions on s.7-F being administrative are incorrect

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge was persuaded by the respondents to consider whether the said decisions were right and he came to the conclusion that the view taken in the said decisions was not right. The judgment delivered by the learned single Judge shows that he had reached this conclusion on re-examining the question

arguments.court_reasoning: Re-examination of statutory scheme confirms quasi-judicial nature

arguments.claim: District Magistrate's power under s.3 deprives tenants of statutory protection, requires quasi-judicial approach and natural justice
Provision for revision to Commissioner implies District Magistrate must give reasons and allow parties to be heard to weigh pros and cons
Commissioner under s.3(3) must hear application, satisfies as to correctness/legality/propriety, acts quasi-judicially

anchor.surface_text: In 1952, clauses (2), (3) and (4) were added to s. 3 by the Amending Act 24 of 1952... The Commissioner shall hear the application made under sub-section (2), as far as may be, within six weeks from the date of making it, and he may, if he is not satisfied as to the correctness, legality or propriety of the order passed by the District Magistrate

arguments.claim: State Government under s.7-F must follow natural justice as proceedings partake of same quasi-judicial character, for ends of justice
Act's policy is tenant protection from eviction, shown by preamble, s.14, s.15; permission deprives statutory right, requires quasi-judicial process
Allahabad High Court view in Murlidhar case incorrect
Obligation to act judicially inferred from statutory scheme affecting rights; follows precedents like Associated Cement Companies and Ridge v Baldwin

anchor.surface_text: When a legislative enactment confers jurisdiction and power on any authority or body to deal with the rights of citizens... This question has been considered by this Court on several occasions. In the Associated Cement Companies Ltd.... that the extent of the area where the principles of natural justice have to be followed and judicial approach has to be adopted, must depend primarily on the nature of the jurisdiction

arguments.claim: Single Judge should refer to larger bench instead of reconsidering Division Bench decisions himself
Permission under s.3 allows eviction without s.3(1) grounds, like under general T.P. Act s.106

anchor.surface_text: In other words, if the District Magistrate grants permission to the landlord, he can sue to evict the tenant under the general provisions of the Transfer of Property Act, as for instance, s. 106.

holdings.text: The jurisdiction conferred on the District Magistrate under s.3 requires him to act quasi-judicially and follow principles of natural justice, including giving parties opportunity to be heard.
holdings.reasoning_summary: DM's permission deprives tenants of statutory protection under s.3(1); revision to Commissioner implies reasons must be given and parties heard to enable review; statutory scheme requires judicial approach.

holdings.text: The Commissioner under s.3(3) must act quasi-judicially, hear the application, and satisfy himself on correctness, legality, or propriety of DM's order.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner shall hear the application made under sub-section (2), as far as may be, within six weeks from the date of making it, and he may, if he is not satisfied as to the correctness, legality or propriety of the order passed by the District Magistrate

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit statutory requirement to 'hear the application'; power to alter/reverse for justice indicates quasi-judicial nature; part of hierarchical scheme protecting tenant rights.

holdings.text: Proceedings before State Government under s.7-F partake of quasi-judicial character, requiring compliance with principles of natural justice including opportunity to parties to be heard.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of s.3 shows DM and Commissioner quasi-judicial; s.7-F revision for 'ends of justice' in same hierarchy affecting tenant rights cannot be administrative; must hear parties to decide fairly.

holdings.text: Revisional order under s.7-F passed without hearing affected parties (respondents) is invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The short question of law which arises in this appeal by special leave is whether the revisional order passed by the State Government of Uttar Pradesh under s. 7-F of the Uttar Pradesh Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947 hereinafter called the Act , is rendered invalid by reason of the fact that before passing the said order,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies quasi-judicial holding to facts: State Government directed revision without hearing tenants, violating natural justice; permission chain collapses, suit incompetent.

holdings.text: Allahabad High Court decisions holding s.7-F power administrative (e.g., Murlidhar case) are incorrect.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Re-examination of statutory scheme, policy of tenant protection, precedents on quasi-judicial duties compel disagreement; prior views ignore nature of rights affected.

holdings.text: A single Judge should not reconsider and overrule prior Division Bench decisions but refer to larger Bench for judicial propriety.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Healthy principles of judicial decorum and hierarchy; not essential to decision but pointed out as appropriate practice.

precedents.citation: Laxman Purshottam Pimputkar v. State of Bombay and others 1

anchor.surface_text: Laxman Purshottam Pimputkar v. State of Bombay and others 1

precedents.case_name: Laxman Purshottam Pimputkar v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: judgment confirmed the view about the nature of the proceedings and the character the jurisdiction contemplated by s. 7-F

precedents.citation: Associated Cement Companies Ltd., Bhupendra Cement Works, Surajpur v. P.N. Sharma and another 1

anchor.surface_text: Associated Cement Companies Ltd., Bhupendra Cement Works, Surajpur v. P.N. Sharma and another 1 , both aspects of this matter have been elaborately examined, and it has been held, adopting the view expressed by the House of Lords-in Ridge Baldwin and others 1  that the extent of the area where the principles of natural justice have to be followed and judicial approach has to be adopted, must depend primarily on the nature of the jurisdiction and the power conferred on any authority or body by statutory provisions to deal with the questions affecting the rights of citizens.

precedents.case_name: Associated Cement Companies Ltd v P.N. Sharma
precedents.cited_proposition: extent of area where principles of natural justice have to be followed depends on nature of jurisdiction and power conferred on authority by statute

anchor.surface_text: Ridge Baldwin and others 1  that the extent of the area where the principles of natural justice have to be followed and judicial approach has to be adopted, must depend primarily on the nature of the jurisdiction and the power conferred on any authority or body by statutory provisions to deal with the questions affecting the rights of citizens. In other words, in that decision this Court has held that the test prescribed by Lord Reid in his judgment in the case of Ridge 2  affords valuable assistance in dealing with the vexed question with which we are concerned in the present appeal.

precedents.cited_proposition: test by Lord Reid on when principles of natural justice apply depending on nature of power

precedents.citation: Narettam Saran v. State of P. 1

anchor.surface_text: Narettam Saran v. State of P. 1 . Indeed. after the learned single Judge had held in the present proceedings that the view taken by the earlier decisions of the Allahabad High Court was erroneous. a Division Bench of the said High Court considered the same question once again and re-affirmed its earlier view vide Murlidhar v. State of U.P. 2 .

precedents.case_name: Narettam Saran v State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: functions under s. 3(2) and s. 3(3) are administrative and no obligation to follow natural justice

anchor.surface_text: Murlidhar v. State of U.P. 2 . We have carefully considered the reasons given by the learned Judges when they re- affirmed the earlier view taken by the High Court of Allahabad on this point. With respect, we are unable to agree with the decision in Murlidhars 2  case.

precedents.cited_proposition: re-affirmed that functions under relevant sections are administrative

anchor.surface_text: Laxman Purshottam Pimputkars 3  case on which the learned single Judge partly relied in support of his conclusion. In that case, this Court was called upon to consider the question whether the revisional jurisdiction conferred on the State Government under s. 79 of the Watan Act was purely administrative. and it came to the conclusion that in exercising the said revisional jurisdiction. the State Government is not acting purely as an administrative authority its decision is judicial or quasi-judicial, and so, it is essential that the State Government should follow the principles of natural justice before reaching its conclusion under that section.

precedents.case_name: Laxman Purshottam Pimputkar v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: revisional jurisdiction under s.79 of Watan Act is quasi-judicial requiring natural justice
precedents.cited_holding: State Government not acting purely administrative but judicial/quasi-judicial

anchor.surface_text: It is the ends of justice which determine the nature of the order which the State Government would pass under s. 7-F, and it seems to us plain that in securing the ends of justice, the State Government cannot but apply principles of natural justice and offer a reasonable opportunity to both the parties while it exercises its jurisdiction under s. 7-F.

outcome.relief_summary: Revisional order under s. 7-F invalid as State Government did not give opportunity of hearing to respondents; permission to sue for ejectment invalid
directions: Learned single Judge should have referred the matter to Division Bench for reconsidering earlier decisions

anchor.surface_text: It is the ends of justice which determine the nature of the order which the State Government would pass under s. 7-F, and it seems to us plain that in securing the ends of justice, the State Government cannot but apply principles of natural justice and offer a reasonable opportunity to both the parties while it exercises its jurisdiction under s. 7-F.

anchor.surface_text: It is the ends of justice which determine the nature of the order which the State Government would pass under s. 7-F, and it seems to us plain that in securing the ends of justice, the State Government cannot but apply principles of natural justice and offer a reasonable opportunity to both the parties while it exercises its jurisdiction under s. 7-F.

The short question of law which arises in this appeal by special leave is whether the revisional order passed by the State Government of Uttar Pradesh under s. 7-F of the Uttar Pradesh Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947 hereinafter called the Act , is rendered invalid by reason of the fact that before passing the said order,

It is the ends of justice which determine the nature of the order which the State Government would pass under s. 7-F, and it seems to us plain that in securing the ends of justice, the State Government cannot but apply principles of natural justice and offer a reasonable opportunity to both the parties while it exercises its jurisdiction under s. 7-F.

It is the ends of justice which determine the nature of the order which the State Government would pass under s. 7-F, and it seems to us plain that in securing the ends of justice, the State Government cannot but apply principles of natural justice and offer a reasonable opportunity to both the parties while it exercises its jurisdiction under s. 7-F.
